prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation involves the husband working from home in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the wife who also works and manages the household and kids.

First, the husband chose to set up his office in the bedroom despite the wife's suggestion to use the basement. The basement is quieter and would presumably cause fewer disturbances. The wife is now struggling to do her work, take care of the kids, and handle chores because the bedroom is his workspace. She can't even use the bathroom in peace when he's on calls.

The key points here are about mutual respect and consideration. The husband chose a location that's convenient for him (better view) but it's creating significant challenges for the wife. The wife is asking him to move to the basement for the sake of minimizing disruptions, which seems reasonable given the available space. The husband's refusal to comply, despite the wife's valid reasons, might make him the one at fault. However, the wife also has a responsibility to be considerate, but in this case, she's already accommodating by trying to keep the kids away. The main issue is the husband's choice of location leading to her inability to function normally. So, it's more about his decision than her being in the wrong. But wait, the question is about the author (the wife) being in the wrong. The wife is not keeping him undisturbed; she's trying to manage the kids and her own tasks. The husband is the one not moving to a less disruptive area. Therefore, the author isn't in the wrong. Answer B.
